background: Land-cover datasets are crucial for research on eco-hydrological processes and earth system modeling. Remote sensing has become widely used as a macro-observing system for land-cover mapping, which can substitute for plant functional type (PFT) as the baseline. Several moderate to fine resolution global land-cover datasets, which are presented in detail in Table I, based on different satellite sensors are available from different research groups. These land-cover datasets listed in Table I have large variability for three reasons: 1) the data quality and properties are different; 2) there is no standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories; and 3) they are not consistent with the Earth System Model’s (ESM) requirements, because the concept of PFT, whose traits represent a combination of spectral relationships, and climatic, ecological, and theoretical assumptions, used in ESMs cannot be mapped directly using remote-sensing land-cover datasets. In addition, the classification accuracies of land-cover datasets vary and are hardly suited for land-process modeling and applications at a river basin scale. The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. For the HRB, most are distributed over an arid region, so the vegetation classification in the HRB based on current land-cover datasets would cause very large uncertainty and may cause great error or even the failure of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.
research objective: In order to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in the HRB, a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation is developed by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands.
challenges: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and in dryland systems among the shrub, grassland, and forest categories because of differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. For the HRB, most are distributed over an arid region, so the vegetation classification in the HRB based on current land-cover datasets would cause very large uncertainty and may cause great error or even the failure of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling.
methods: A mosaic of the HRB is made using Landsat/TM imagery. The mosaic of Landsat/TM is used as the base image and all HJ-1/CCD images are automatically corrected through the image-to-image registration method. Converting the DN values of the HJ-1/CCD images to top of atmosphere (TOA) radiance with given calibration coefficients. Removing the atmospheric effects of remote-sensing images to obtain the surface reflectance. After the preprocessing has been done, all the HJ-1/CCD images within 1 month are subset and mosaicked; consequently, 10 mosaics for 10 months in the HRB are made and time series of the HRB mosaics from HJ-1/CCD are constructed.
dataset: The HJ-1/CCD remote-sensing data used in this research were provided by the China Centre for Resources Satellite Data and Application (CRESDA, http://www.cresda.com). The Landsat TM/ETM+ data were downloaded from the USGS website (http://landsat.usgs.gov/). The MODIS data were downloaded from the NASA Goddard Space Flight Center (http://ladsweb.nascom.nasa.gov/). The VHSR data were from Google Earth by Google Inc.
findings: The confusion matrix is used to evaluate the classification accuracy, showing an overall classification accuracy of over 90% in the HRB, which is quite higher than previous approaches. Furthermore, a ground campaign was performed to evaluate the accuracy of crop classification and an overall accuracy of 84.09% for the crop classification was achieved.

background: Long time series of land cover changes (LCCs) are critical in the analysis of long-term climate, environmental, and ecological changes. Although several moderate to fine resolution global land cover datasets have been publicly released and they show strong consistency at the global scale, they have large deviations at the regional scale; furthermore, high-quality land cover datasets from before 2000 are not available and the classification consistency among different datasets is not very good. Remote sensing has become widely used for global land cover mapping, as it can capture the changes of land cover quickly. Until now, several moderate to fine resolution global land cover datasets have been publicly released and the spatial resolutions of these products are between 1 km and 30 m. They show strong consistency at the global scale, but they have large deviations at the regional scale. The main problems include: (1) most of the land cover datasets have a relatively low resolution (500 m and lower) and their accuracies are usually lower than 75%; among the released datasets, GlobeLand30 and FROM-GLC30 have a spatial resolution of 30 m, and their overall accuracies are 80% and 72% respectively; (2) the classification accuracy of these released datasets at the regional scale is much lower than the claimed accuracy, especially at heterogeneous areas, which is difficult to meet the modeling requirements, and (3) all the datasets are after 2000 and do not have long time series and therefore cannot support the analysis of long-term climate, environmental, and ecological changes.
research objective: Therefore, by taking the advantages of the two categories of satellite data, we proposed a new time series land cover mapping method based on machine learning and it, thereafter, is applied to Heihe River Basin (HRB) for verification purposes.
challenges: Many comprehensive classification methods, such as GlobeLand30 using Landsat series satellite data have been developed but the ones with high accuracy usually require manual intervention; thus, more than 10 years’ land cover maps with areas over 140,000 km2 do not allow a lot of manual intervention. Although methods based on time series analysis like LCMM have the capability for making high-quality land cover datasets, a 16-day revisiting period of Landsat series satellite data does not support constructing time series data at HRB. Although machine learning methods, such as FROM-GLC30 have a lot of advantages and have been employed to map land cover using remote sensing imagery, they are usually limited by sampling amount and representativity; the requirement for consistency on data of these methods cannot be met by Landsat series satellite data.
methods: Firstly, the high-quality land cover datasets at HRB from 2011–2015, which were retrieved using the LCMM method, are used for quickly and accurately making training samples. Secondly, a strategy for transferring the training samples after 2011 to earlier years is established. Thirdly, the random forest model is employed to train the selected yearly samples and a land cover map for every year is subsequently made. Finally, comprehensive analysis and validation are carried out for evaluation.
dataset: Firstly, the high-quality land cover datasets at HRB from 2011–2015, which were retrieved using the LCMM method, are used for quickly and accurately making training samples.
findings: In this study, a long time series land cover dataset including 1986, 1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014, and 2015 is finally made and an average precision of about 90% is achieved. It is the longest time series land cover map with 30 m resolution at HRB and the dataset has good time continuity and stability.

Definition.Question: How is 'land-cover classification accuracy' evaluated in remote sensing datasets?
Definition.Answer: Land-cover classification accuracy in remote sensing datasets is evaluated using methods like the confusion matrix, which assesses the agreement between classified land-cover types and reference data. This evaluation can also involve ground campaigns to verify classification accuracy, particularly for specific categories like crop classification. The goal is to achieve high overall classification accuracy, typically measured as a percentage.

Definition.Question: What challenges arise in 'vegetation classification' in arid regions using remote sensing data?
Definition.Answer: Vegetation classification in arid regions using remote sensing data faces challenges due to high uncertainty in classifying categories such as cropland, grassland, shrub, and forest. These challenges are exacerbated by differences in minimum threshold requirements for forest cover and the variability in vegetation types, leading to potential errors in eco-hydrological and land-process modeling at the river basin scale.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques using Landsat series satellite data compare to the HJ-1/CCD images in terms of classification accuracy and application for land cover mapping?
Comparison.Answer: Landsat series satellite data provides moderate to fine resolution images and are widely used for global land cover mapping. They are often limited by the 16-day revisiting period, which can affect the construction of time series data. The HJ-1/CCD images allow for surface reflectance retrieval and are corrected automatically through image-to-image registration, providing higher classification accuracy in specific areas like the Heihe River Basin, with an overall accuracy of over 90%.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when using remote sensing for land cover classification between cropland and grassland categories versus between shrub, grassland, and forest categories?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges in classifying cropland and grassland categories primarily arise from the high uncertainty in land-cover classification due to similar spectral properties in optical remotely sensed imagery. In contrast, the classification among shrub, grassland, and forest categories in dryland systems is complicated by differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover, adding to the uncertainty and potential errors in eco-hydrological and land-process modeling, especially in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin.

Comparison.Question: In what ways does the use of machine learning for land cover mapping differ from traditional methods in terms of data consistency and sample representativity?
Comparison.Answer: Machine learning methods, such as those using random forest models, capitalize on high-quality training samples from previous years to create land cover maps with improved precision, achieving about 90% accuracy over long time series. Traditional methods may require more manual intervention and struggle with data consistency, particularly when using Landsat series data, which may not meet the consistency requirements due to limited sampling amount and representativity issues.

Interpretation.Question: What methodologies can be inferred from the use of mosaic creation and image-to-image registration for improving land-cover classification accuracy in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The creation of mosaics using Landsat/TM imagery and subsequent image-to-image registration can improve classification accuracy by providing a consistent and corrected base image. This allows for enhanced detection of changes in land cover over time, which is particularly beneficial in arid regions where classification challenges are prevalent due to subtle vegetation differences.

Interpretation.Question: How can machine learning techniques be utilized to address the challenge of limited temporal resolution in remote sensing datasets for long-term land cover mapping?
Interpretation.Answer: Machine learning techniques, like the use of random forest models, can be employed to enhance temporal resolution by leveraging high-quality datasets from specific years to create training samples. These samples can be transferred to earlier years, allowing for the creation of consistent land cover maps over a long time series, despite limitations in the temporal resolution of satellite data.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential implications of discrepancies in land-cover dataset resolutions and accuracies on eco-hydrological modeling at the river basin scale?
Interpretation.Answer: Discrepancies in land-cover dataset resolutions and accuracies can lead to significant uncertainty in eco-hydrological modeling, particularly at the river basin scale. These discrepancies may result in errors or failures in modeling efforts due to misclassification of vegetation types, which are critical for accurately representing land processes and their interactions with hydrological cycles.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes contribute to the high variability in land-cover datasets, especially when classifying continuous vegetation into discrete categories?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The high variability in land-cover datasets arises due to differences in data quality and properties, the lack of a standard approach for classifying continuous vegetation cover into discrete categories, and inconsistencies with Earth System Model’s requirements. Additionally, classification accuracies vary and are often not suited for modeling applications at a river basin scale.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why do land-cover classification accuracies from optical remotely sensed imagery encounter high uncertainty, particularly in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery occurs most frequently between the cropland and grassland categories and among shrub, grassland, and forest categories in dryland systems. This is due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover, which is particularly challenging in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What underlying reasons have led to the development of new methods for land-cover mapping with fine spatial resolution in regions like HRB?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: In regions like the Heihe River Basin, existing land-cover datasets have large deviations at the regional scale and do not meet the modeling requirements due to their relatively low resolution and accuracy. This has necessitated the development of new methods that utilize multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data to map land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the outcomes of utilizing multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data for mapping land cover in arid regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data can improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling by reducing the uncertainty in land-cover classification, especially in distinguishing between cropland and grassland categories. This approach, when applied to the Heihe River Basin (HRB), resulted in an overall classification accuracy of over 90%, which is higher than previous methods.

Causal Consequence.Question: What impact does constructing a time series of land cover maps have on analyzing long-term climate and environmental changes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Constructing a time series of land cover maps facilitates the analysis of long-term climate, environmental, and ecological changes by providing consistent and high-quality datasets over an extended period. In the Heihe River Basin, a long time series land cover dataset with 30 m resolution was created, achieving an average precision of about 90%, and providing good time continuity and stability.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective behind developing a comprehensive method for mapping monthly land cover with fine spatial resolution?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling in the Heihe River Basin (HRB) by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatio-temporal resolutions and spectral bands.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is there a need to propose a new time series land cover mapping method based on machine learning for the Heihe River Basin?
Goal Orientation.Answer: There is a need to propose a new time series land cover mapping method to take advantage of different categories of satellite data and address the challenge of creating high-quality land cover datasets with a long time series, which are crucial for analyzing long-term climate, environmental, and ecological changes.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the necessary steps to preprocess remote sensing images for accurate land-cover classification in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Preprocessing involves creating a mosaic of the region using Landsat/TM imagery, performing automatic image-to-image registration corrections for HJ-1/CCD images, converting DN values to top of atmosphere radiance using calibration coefficients, and removing atmospheric effects to obtain surface reflectance. Subsequently, images are subset and mosaicked to construct a time series of mosaics.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can multisource remotely sensed data be utilized to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological and land-process modeling?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A comprehensive method can be developed by using multiple classifiers and multisource remotely sensed data with different spatial resolutions and spectral bands to map land cover with fine spatial resolution and more categories of crop/vegetation. This approach aims to reduce uncertainties in land-cover classification, particularly in arid regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural approach can be taken to create a long time series land cover dataset with high precision?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedural approach involves using high-quality land cover datasets to quickly and accurately make training samples, establishing a strategy for transferring these samples to earlier years, employing the random forest model to train yearly samples, and subsequently creating a land cover map for each year. Comprehensive analysis and validation are then carried out to evaluate the dataset's precision and continuity.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the creation of high-resolution land-cover datasets using remote sensing techniques?
Enablement.Answer: The use of platforms like Google Earth Engine for data processing, along with data from satellite sensors such as Landsat series and MODIS, has enabled the creation of high-resolution land-cover datasets. These advancements allow for efficient data processing and classification, improving the accuracy and precision of land-cover datasets.

Expectation.Question: What challenges are anticipated in using optical remotely sensed imagery for land-cover classification in arid regions?
Expectation.Answer: The highest uncertainty in land-cover classification from optical remotely sensed imagery arises due to the difficulty in distinguishing between cropland and grassland categories, as well as among shrub, grassland, and forest categories in dryland systems, particularly due to differences in the minimum threshold required for forest cover. This uncertainty is particularly challenging for regions like the HRB, which are distributed over arid areas.

Expectation.Question: Why might machine learning methods face limitations when applied to land-cover mapping using remote sensing imagery?
Expectation.Answer: Machine learning methods for land-cover mapping using remote sensing imagery are often limited by the amount and representativity of the sampling data available. Furthermore, the requirement for consistency in data used by these methods cannot always be met with existing satellite data like the Landsat series, which hinders the ability to construct consistent time series data.

Judgmental.Question: How effective are multisource remotely sensed data and multiple classifiers in improving the accuracy of land-cover mapping in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Using multisource remotely sensed data and multiple classifiers has proven effective in improving land-cover mapping accuracy, especially in arid regions like the Heihe River Basin. The approach helps address the high uncertainty between categories such as cropland and grassland, achieving an overall classification accuracy of over 90%.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways might machine learning enhance the creation of land cover maps, particularly for datasets with long temporal spans?
Judgmental.Answer: Machine learning can enhance the creation of land cover maps by automating the classification process, reducing the need for manual intervention, and improving consistency across datasets. Techniques like the random forest model can utilize training samples over multiple years to produce accurate yearly maps, as demonstrated in creating a long time series dataset with high precision at the Heihe River Basin.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how remote sensing can effectively handle the variability and uncertainty in land-cover classification, especially in arid regions.
Assertion.Answer: Remote sensing can be used for land-cover mapping by employing multiple classifiers and multisource data with different spatial and temporal resolutions. A mosaic of images, like Landsat/TM, is used as a base, and other data like HJ-1/CCD are corrected and processed to remove atmospheric effects. This method helps in achieving higher accuracy despite variability, particularly in arid regions.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why datasets before 2000 have such inconsistencies in classification accuracy compared to more recent datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Prior to 2000, high-quality land cover datasets were scarce, and classification methods were less advanced. The spatial resolution was usually lower, and the accuracy did not meet the requirements for detailed modeling, especially in heterogeneous areas. Recent datasets have benefited from advancements like machine learning and multisource data integration, improving accuracy and consistency.
